III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
Section (1)An institution shall maintain employee records for each
Description employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this rule:
(f) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic violations
from either of the following entities:
(i) Directly from the Michigan state police or the equivalent
state law enforcement agency, Canadian province, or other
country where the person usually resides or has resided in the
previous 5 years.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff have criminal history and have provided middle names
instead of first names to pass a background check.
Investigation Documents Reviewed:
On October 15, 2025, sixty employee files were reviewed. Sixty of
sixty employees had either a driver’s license or identification card
on file. Sixty of sixty employees had an I-Chat result on file which
was run in the name that was on their driver’s license or
identification card.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance with having a record of any
convictions for all employees on file. All sixty employees I-Chat’s
were run in the correct name on their identification and not in their
middle names.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
Section (1)An institution shall maintain employee records for each
Description employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this rule:
(g) If the employee has criminal convictions, the institution shall
complete a written evaluation of the convictions that addresses
the nature of the conviction, the length of time since the
conviction, and the relationship of the conviction to regulated
activity for the purpose of determining suitability for employment in
the institution.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The facility is not completing individual criminal assessments but
rather using the same information for several employees.
Investigation Documents Reviewed:
On October 15, 2025, sixty employee files were reviewed. Nine of
sixty employees had criminal history records. Seven of nine
2

employees had the exact same assessment for their criminal
record, which is as follows:
Written Evaluation Regarding Suitability for Employment
[Staff Name]
The applicant’s record reflects a non-violent offence. No further
legal issues or similar incidents have been reported since that
time.
Nature of the Conviction:
This offense involved is a non-violent violation. It did not involve
harm to others, violence, or behavior indicating risk to vulnerable
populations.
Time Since Conviction:
The significant passage of time, combined with a demonstrated
record of law-abiding behavior since, indicates rehabilitation and
maturity.
Relations to Youth Aide Role:
The offense does not directly relate to the responsibilities at
Michigan Youth Treatment Center (MYTC), which involves
providing supervision, guidance, and support to youth in a secure
treatment environment. The violation did not involve abuse,
neglect or misconduct toward others and does not suggest a risk
of inappropriate behavior in a youth care setting.
Suitability for Employment:
Based on the age of the offense, its minor nature, and the
absence of any subsequent incidents, this conviction does not
appear to disqualify the applicant from serving as an employee at
Michigan Youth Treatment Center. The applicant has
demonstrated personal growth.
It was noted in one of the seven files, the applicant had a
domestic violence charge that would be considered a violent
violation as that could include harm to others, violence, or
behavior indicating risk to vulnerable populations.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as the assessments for
seven of the nine employees with criminal history were not an
individual assessment based on each of the employees criminal
record but rather a generic letter in each file.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
6/25/2025 Original Study, CAP Approved 6/30/2025

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
Section (1)An institution shall maintain employee records for each
Description employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this rule:
(h) A statement from the employee regarding any convictions.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The facility is not obtaining a statement from employees regarding
any convictions.
Investigation Documents Reviewed:
On October 15, 2025, sixty employee files were reviewed. Nine of
sixty employees had criminal history records. Six of nine
employees had the exact same statement for their criminal
convictions, which is as follows:
To whom it may concern:
I received a non-violent offense. I take accountability and
responsibility for my actions; I am, and I will make better choices
in the future. Furthermore, I have had no legal trouble since the
within incident.
[Signed by employee]
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance for obtaining a written
statement from employees regarding their convictions. The
statement for six of the nine employees with criminal history was
not an individual statement based on each of the employees
criminal record but rather a generic statement in each file.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
6/25/2025 Original Study, CAP Approved 6/30/2025
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4162 Seclusion within secure and nonsecure
Section facilities; seclusion plan; prohibitions; reduction and elimination
Description (11) All seclusion will be prohibited effective November 1, 2022.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff are secluding youth during shower time in their rooms, they
are given consequences if they leave their bedroom.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
October 13, 2025. Youth A said all youth are required to be in
their rooms during shower program. Youth A said his door
remains unlocked however if you come out of your room you “fail
4

your day”. Youth A said he is in his room for about forty-five
minutes for shower program.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
October 13, 2025. Youth B said all youth are required to be in
their rooms during shower program or it would be a “PREA
violation”. Youth B said the bedroom doors are unlocked but if you
exit your room you will loose “25 points and basically fail your
day”. Youth B said he is in his room for 60 to 90 minutes per day
for shower program.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
October 13, 2025. Youth C said all youth must remain in their
bedroom during shower time unless it is their turn. Youth C said
the doors are unlocked but if you leave your room, you will “get
points taken away”. Youth C said he can exit his room once
everyone is done showering which can take “about an hour”.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
October 13, 2025. Youth D said all youth must go to their rooms
for shower program. Youth D said the doors may be cracked open
but they may not leave their room unless it is their turn to shower.
Youth D said he was told that he had to remain in his room
because it was a “PREA policy”. Youth D said shower program
usually lasts about 45-minutes a day.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on October 8, 2025.
Staff 1 reported youth are required to be in their bedrooms during
shower time with the doors unlocked. Staff 1 said that if youth exit
their rooms they will “fail their day”.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on October 15, 2025.
Staff 2 said she works second shift which is when youth complete
shower program. Staff 2 said after dinner the youth return to their
units and get their shower caddy and new clothing and then are
required to go into their rooms. Staff 2 said the youth’s doors are
unlocked however they are not allowed out of their rooms and if
the come out they are told it is a “PREA violation” and they are
given consequences. Staff 2 said the consequences for them
leaving their room would be a zero on their point sheet for shower
program time and could make them fail their day depending on
how many other points they have from the day.
Supervisor was interviewed via telephone on October 5, 2025.
Supervisor said shower program begins at 6pm and all youth are
required to go to their rooms, however the door remains unlocked.
5

Supervisor said the youth come out of their rooms one at a time to
take a shower and once everyone has showered, they are all
allowed out of their rooms. Supervisor said if the youth come out
of their rooms during shower program it is considered a “a major
violation” and points are deducted, and it will affect their level.
Documents Reviewed:
• Michigan Youth Treatment Center Seclusion Variance dated
June 6, 2025, was reviewed. The variance does not allow
for youth to be secluded during shower time.
• Michigan Youth Treatment Center Use of Seclusion Policy
was reviewed. The policy does not allow for use of
seclusion during shower time and has very specific
expectations for the use of seclusion, the monitoring during
seclusions, and assessments and notification for post-
seclusion.
• Email on July 30, 2025, from Former Chief Administrator to
MYTC Supervisors and MDHHS Administration. The email
stated “Hello Team,
Following up on our recent phone call, and in alignment
with DCWL compliance standards, the following procedures
are to be implemented effective immediately to ensure
the safety of all Trailblazers during the shower program:
During Shower Program:
o A supervisor must enter the control room and place
all doors in the unlocked position using the
master control board.
o The expectation is for all Trailblazers to return to
their rooms during the shower program. However,
youth have the right to decline returning to their
rooms.
o If a Trailblazer refuses to go to their room, they must
be allowed to sit in the day area during the shower
program.
o At the conclusion of the shower program, all
Trailblazers are expected to report to the day
room for their nightly goal meeting.
• Email on July 30, 2025, from DCWL Consultant to Former
Chief Administrator. The email stated “Good Afternoon,
I wanted to let you know that I was able to connect with
your PREA Analyst, and she told me that PREA does not
require youth to be locked in their bedrooms for shower
time so the guidelines you have established will meet both
licensing and PREA expectations.”
• Email on September 8, 2025, from DCWL Consultant to
Former Chief Administrator. The email stated “The key is
6

that the rooms are not locked. They can ask them to go to
unlocked rooms and that is not an issue. The problem is
them locking them in the rooms so they cannot come out.
They cannot provide consequences for not staying in the
room or stand in the doorway and force them to be in the
rooms but asking them to be in their rooms for shower time
or having that be the standard is not an issue. I would also
recommend getting a door on the shower area…they use a
curtain right now and have told me it is for safety of any
youth that may harm themselves and while I can
understand that I also think leaving that area open could be
a risk for supervision if a youth were to try to sneak in there
and for issues while youth are showering and only have a
curtain between them and the milieu area.”
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per staff and youth
interviews, the youth are being secluded in their bedrooms during
shower time which is prohibited.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR 2025SIC0000881 Approved 8/26/25, CAP Approved 9/15/25
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
